RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 Using magic is also tiring, and after using energy reserves, can eat away at fat and even cause atrophy in…

@Kiraofthewind1 Using magic is also tiring, and after using energy reserves, can eat away at fat and even cause atrophy in extreme cases. Mages ideally should be somewhat fat, though their weight will fluctuate with heavy magic use. One can also exercise one's energy reserves with practice.
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 Morality is an interesting question in magic. It's hard to do magic which morally repulses you, hence a hug…
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 The limits of physics provide limits for the magic, eg one can't create or destroy matter. One's mind is al…

@Kiraofthewind1 Morality is an interesting question in magic. It's hard to do magic which morally repulses you, hence a huge part of a necromancer's  training, for example, is becoming desensitized to corpses. A person who wouldn't hurt a fly will struggle to do magic to harm someone, etc.

@Kiraofthewind1 The limits of physics provide limits for the magic, eg one can't create or destroy matter. One's mind is also a limit: your ability to multitask, focus, or comprehend something limits your magic. This is what tends to lead to specialization in one field or another.
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 These phenomena include visions of the future, hallucinations, inexplicable entities that inhabit the realm…
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 It's a hard system, in the way that it has simple precepts with complicated results. Still figuring it out…

@Kiraofthewind1 These phenomena include visions of the future, hallucinations, inexplicable entities that inhabit the realm of legend, said by some to roam Etnuet, shaping events to their preference...stuff like that. ☺️

@Kiraofthewind1 It's a hard system, in the way that it has simple precepts with complicated results. Still figuring it out tbh. But then there's a whole area of unexplained supernatural phenomena that is basically soft magic. This tends to involve raw magic, aka I organically generated magic.
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 Magic can be done instinctually no problem. The real thing is learning to apply it effectively & efficientl…

@Kiraofthewind1 Magic can be done instinctually no problem. The real thing is learning to apply it effectively & efficiently. The closer your understanding of, say, how heat is produced, is to the truth, the more effective your magic will be at producing heat. Learning to focus is important too.
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 As mentioned last week, one system divides magic into elemental dualities. This system isn't accurate. It's…

@Kiraofthewind1 As mentioned last week, one system divides magic into elemental dualities. This system isn't accurate. It's hard to divide magic up when it comes to the same principle: applying magic by envisioning matter and energy behaving in specific ways. But ppl are still figuring that out.
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 One thing worth mentioning is that all living things have an anti-magic shield which prevents any magical m…
RT @LyraMeurer: @Kiraofthewind1 Ability to use magic is a genetic trait in Etnuet. Humans & similar have ~50% occurrence of magic ability,…

@Kiraofthewind1 One thing worth mentioning is that all living things have an anti-magic shield which prevents any magical meddling inside the body. Some ppl have the ability to penetrate the anti-magic shield, with which they can heal or harm. Not having this shield would be a genetic condition.

@Kiraofthewind1 Ability to use magic is a genetic trait in Etnuet. Humans & similar have ~50% occurrence of magic ability, whereas a dragon without magic is extremely rare (they can't fly without it). Lots of animals have evolved to use magic in specific ways too, from fish to salamanders.

FTR, I don't think any character is pure nor is any 100% irredeemable. This is also the point. There's so much nuance, which is beautiful. Jules has made mistakes, Rue is in a very dark place, but they're young & fallible. This is how you learn: by hurting ppl & yourself.

We're all responsible for our own choices, how we face our pain etc. If you think Jules is responsible for maintaining Rue's sobriety and emotional state, then you've fallen for Rue's junkie BS. Her sobriety was never solid bc she didn't do it for herself. That's the point.

Been seeing people rag on Jules bc she "made Rue relapse." The whole 1st season of #Euphoria establishes that Rue views her sobriety as dependent on others when ACTUALLY she's responsible for her own behavior. She didn't HAVE to relapse, she chose to. Smh.

Echoes of the same theme are used into the ending credits, the "Weronika" and "Veronique" themes, little 30 second installments on the track. A lovely finishing touch, a reminder that the romance with Rue is also a dangerous journey into the unknown. 9/

This entering into the unknown overlays scenes of Jules getting catfished. She's traveling into unknown territory, falling in love with someone who doesn't exist, exploring what she thinks is heaven. It's the perfect song for the moment, IMO. 8/

The lyrics of "Concerto en Mi Mineur" are a setting of Canto II of Dante's Paradiso. He speaks to the reader in their "little boat" and urges them to follow, for, "The seas I sail have never been sailed before," and invokes the muses as he journeys to heaven. 7/

I feel it harkens to the bond between Rue & Jules, how horrific for Jules it would be if Rue were to die. After S2E1, I see the similarity between them too: addicts of certain feelings and addicted to each other, mirroring each other. 6/

The film is about 2 women who look exactly the same: Veronique, who lives in France, & Weronika, who lives in Poland. They don't know each other or interact. Weronika dies while singing the song in a concert, & far away, Veronique feels a deep, inexplicable grief. 5/

It's actually from the soundtrack of La Double Vie de Veronique, a Polish film. In the universe of the film, "Concerto en mi Mineur" was created by a fictional composer named Van den Budenmayer. 4/

https://t.co/JP3gBPfPbB

I have more to say on Zbigniew Preisner's "Concerto en mi Mineur," which plays over the sequence where Jules takes photos for, falls in love with, and imagines living with Tyler. I have loved that song since I was literally 16 and seeing it appear in a TV show blew my mind. 3/

"Stabat Mater" is also based on a trio of voices and a trio of strings. There's a couple trios you could read into that: Jules, Rue, & Jules' mother; Jules, Rue, & Nate/Tyler.
